text: 1. Now follows the Mahâvrata ceremony.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 2. After having killed V ri tra, Indra became great. When he became great, then there was the Mahâvrata (the great work). This is why the Mahâvrata ceremony is called Mahâvrata.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 3. Some people say: 'Let the priest make two (recitations with the offering of the) â g ya (ghee) on that day,' but the right thing is one 1 .

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 4. He who desires prosperity should use the hymn, pra vo devâyâgnaye (Rv. III, 13, 1).

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 5. He who desires increase should use the hymn, vi s o vi s o atithim (Rv. VIII, 74, 1).

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 6. The people (visa h ) indeed are increase 1 , and therefore he (the sacrificer) becomes increased.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 7. But (some say), there is the word atithim (in that hymn, which means a guest or stranger, asking for food). Let him not therefore take that hymn. Verily, the atithi (stranger) is able 2 to go begging.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 8. 'No,' he said, 'let him take that hymn.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 9. 'For he who follows the good road and obtains distinction, he is an atithi (guest) 3 .

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 10. 'They do not consider him who is not so, worthy to be (called) an atithi (guest).

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 11. 'Therefore let him by all means take that hymn.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 12. If he takes that hymn, let him place the (second) tristich, âganma v ri trahantamam, 'we came near to the victorious,' first.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 13. For people worship the whole year (performing the Gavâmayana sacrifice) wishing for this day (the last but one)--they do come near.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 14. The (next following) three tristichs begin with an Anush t ubh 4 . Now Brahman is Gâyatrî, speech is Anush t ubh. He thus joins speech with Brahman.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 15. He who desires glory should use the hymn, abodhy agni h samidhâ ganânâm (Rv. V, 1, 1).

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 16. He who desires offspring and cattle should use the hymn, hotâ g anish t a k etana h (Rv. II, 5, 1).

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 157:1 That it should be one only is proved from the types, i. e. from other sacrifices, that have to be followed in the performance of the Mahâvrata. The first type is the Agnish t oma, where one s astra is enjoined as â g ya s astra, viz. pra vo devâyâgnaye. In the Vi s va g it, which has to follow the Agnish t oma, another hymn is put in its place, viz. agni m naro dîdhitibhi h . In the Mahâvrata, which has to follow the Vi s va g it, some people recommend the use of both these hymns. But that is wrong, for there must be in the sacrifices which follow the Agnish t oma twelve s astras altogether; and if there were two here, instead of one, we should get a total of thirteen.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 158:1 The word visa h , which occurs in the hymn, means people. The commentator says that because the Vai s yas or tradespeople increase their capital, therefore they are called increase.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 158:2 Able, or liable; cf. Ait. Âr. II, 3, 5, 7.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 158:3 Atithi is here explained by yo bhavati, and bhavati is explained as walking on the good road. One expects yo vâ atati. The obtaining of distinction is probably derived from ati, above, in atithi.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 158:4 In the first and second the Anush t ubh is followed by two Gâyatrîs.
